title: Calbuco
meta_title: Calbuco Volcano — 2015 Eruption, History & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Calbuco is a 1,974 m stratovolcano in southern Chile. Its dramatic 2015 VEI 4 eruption stunned the world. Full eruption history, hazards, and visitor information.

quick_answer.what: Calbuco is an active andesitic stratovolcano rising to 1,974 m (6,476 ft) in the Chilean Lake District, immediately southeast of Lake Llanquihue, approximately 30 km from the city of Puerto Montt.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted April 2015 with a sudden VEI 4 eruption that produced massive eruption columns and pyroclastic flows with almost no warning.
quick_answer.famous_for: The dramatic April 22-23, 2015 eruption, which occurred with virtually no precursory warning and produced a mushroom-shaped eruption column photographed and shared worldwide.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — the 2015 eruption demonstrated that Calbuco can produce violent eruptions with minimal warning. Approximately 400,000 people live within 100 km.

hero.name: Calbuco
hero.subtitle: Southern Chile's Sleeping Giant That Woke Without Warning
hero.region: Los Lagos Region, Chilean Lake District

key_facts_box.region: Los Lagos Region, Chilean Lake District
key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Nazca Plate beneath South American Plate
key_facts_box.summit_crater: 400-500 m wide, capped by lava dome complex

overview.content: Calbuco is an active stratovolcano in the Chilean Lake District, standing 1,974 m (6,476 ft) above sea level immediately southeast of Llanquihue, Chile's second-largest lake. Approximately 30 km northeast of the regional capital Puerto Montt and 20 km south of the popular tourist town of Puerto Varas, Calbuco is one of the most frequently active and hazardous volcanoes in the southern Chilean Andes, with 36 recorded eruptions spanning from approximately 8460 BCE to 2015. The volcano achieved global fame on April 22, 2015, when it erupted suddenly and violently in a VEI 4 event that produced towering eruption columns reaching 15 km altitude, pyroclastic flows on multiple flanks, and widespread ashfall across the Lake District and into Argentina — all with virtually no precursory warning. Photographs of the immense mushroom-shaped eruption cloud, illuminated by spectacular volcanic lightning against the twilight sky, circulated worldwide within hours and became some of the most iconic volcanic images of the 21st century. Calbuco's elongated SW-NE edifice is capped by a 400-500 m wide summit crater hosting a lava dome complex that has been progressively enlarged by successive eruptions, most notably during the 1893-1894 event. The complex eruptive history includes two VEI 5 eruptions in the early Holocene and a catastrophic late Pleistocene edifice collapse that produced a 3 km³ debris avalanche reaching the shores of Lake Llanquihue. Calbuco sits along the Southern Andean Volcanic Arc, where the Nazca Plate subducts beneath the South American Plate, forming the Ring of Fire's southeastern segment alongside its scenic neighbor Osorno volcano.

geology_and_formation.content:
Calbuco is a product of the Southern Andean Volcanic Arc, generated by the subduction of the Nazca Plate beneath the South American Plate at the Peru-Chile Trench, approximately 150 km to the west. At Calbuco's latitude of 41.3°S, the subducting Nazca Plate descends at an angle of roughly 25-30° and reaches depths of approximately 100-150 km beneath the volcanic arc, driving dehydration reactions that trigger partial melting of the overlying mantle wedge and producing the andesitic to basaltic andesitic magma characteristic of the volcano.

The volcanic complex has a long and violent construction history. Edifice building began in the late Pleistocene, but an intermediate structure collapsed catastrophically during a sector failure, producing a debris avalanche estimated at 3 km³ in volume that traveled northwestward to the shores of Lake Llanquihue. The hummocky terrain between the modern volcano and the lake preserves the topographic signature of this collapse deposit. The modern edifice has been built within and atop the remnants of this collapsed structure over the Holocene. The summit is elongated in a SW-NE direction, reflecting structural control by regional fault systems associated with the Liquiñe-Ofqui Fault Zone, a major strike-slip fault that runs for over 1,000 km through the southern Chilean Andes.

The capping lava dome complex — enlarged during the 1893-1894 eruption and again during subsequent events — represents viscous andesitic magma that has been repeatedly extruded into the summit crater. Calbuco's magma is andesitic (typically 55-62% SiO₂), which is viscous enough to produce explosive eruptions but can also generate lava flows under the right conditions. Petrological analysis of the 2015 eruption products revealed evidence of magma mixing — the injection of hotter, more mafic (basaltic) magma from deeper in the system into a cooler, more evolved andesitic reservoir at shallow depth — as a likely eruption trigger. This rapid magma mixing may explain why the 2015 eruption occurred with so little precursory warning: the trigger came from depth so quickly that it bypassed the gradual shallow pressurization signals that monitoring networks typically detect weeks to days before an eruption.

eruption_history_overview.content: The Smithsonian GVP records 36 eruptions for Calbuco spanning from approximately 8460 BCE to 2015 CE. The Holocene record reveals a volcano capable of large explosive eruptions across a range of magnitudes: two events in the early Holocene (~8460 and ~6760 BCE) reached VEI 5 — the same magnitude as the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens — and multiple subsequent eruptions reached VEI 4, including those around 7550, 5820, and 5030 BCE, as well as approximately 160 CE, 710 CE, 1893, and 2015. The historical record (post-1600 CE) documents approximately 14 eruptions, with the 1893-1894 eruption being the largest in recent centuries prior to 2015. A notable cluster of activity occurred in the early 20th century, with eruptions recorded in 1906, 1907, 1909, 1911-1912, 1917, 1927, 1928, and 1929 — eight eruptions in just 24 years. Subsequent events in 1932, 1945, 1961, and 1972 were smaller (VEI 2), followed by a 43-year quiet period before the dramatic 2015 eruption. The pattern suggests Calbuco alternates between periods of frequent moderate eruptions and decades-long pauses, with no reliable indicator of when a quiescent period will end catastrophically.

subsections.title: Early Holocene VEI 5 Eruptions (~8460 and ~6760 BCE)
subsections.content: Calbuco's largest known eruptions occurred in the early Holocene. The eruption approximately 8460 BCE and another around 6760 BCE both reached VEI 5, producing major pyroclastic flows and widespread tephra deposits across the Chilean Lake District. These events demonstrate that Calbuco is capable of eruptions an order of magnitude larger than 2015. The VEI 5 classification indicates eruption columns reaching 10-25 km into the atmosphere and the ejection of over 1 km³ of material.

subsections.title: The 1893-1894 Eruption (VEI 4)
subsections.content: Beginning January 7, 1893, Calbuco produced one of the largest historical eruptions in southern Chile. The VEI 4 eruption generated powerful explosive columns, pyroclastic flows, and lahars that descended toward Lake Llanquihue and the Rio Maullin. The eruption continued until 1894 and concluded with lava dome emplacement in the summit crater. Ashfall was reported across a wide area of southern Chile and into Argentina.

subsections.title: The April 2015 Eruption (VEI 4) — The Eruption That Stunned the World
subsections.content:
On the evening of April 22, 2015, Calbuco erupted with extraordinary violence and virtually no warning. The volcano had been quiet since a minor VEI 2 eruption in 1972, a dormancy period of 43 years. Although SERNAGEOMIN maintained a monitoring network, only approximately 3 hours of mild seismicity preceded the event — far shorter than the days to weeks of precursory activity typically observed before major stratovolcanic eruptions. At approximately 6:05 PM local time (21:05 UTC), the first of two major explosive pulses began, sending an eruption column approximately 15 km into the atmosphere. The eruption produced pyroclastic flows that descended multiple flanks, volcanic lightning that illuminated the massive eruption cloud in hundreds of individual bolts, and heavy ashfall across the Lake District.

A second, even more powerful explosive pulse occurred in the early hours of April 23, beginning around 1:00 AM local time and lasting several hours, generating additional pyroclastic flows and extending the ashfall zone significantly eastward into Argentina. SERNAGEOMIN declared a red alert and ordered the evacuation of approximately 4,000-6,500 people from communities within a 20 km radius of the summit. Ashfall of several centimeters was recorded in towns across the region, including Puerto Montt, disrupting aviation (flights were cancelled across southern Chile and Argentina), contaminating water supplies, collapsing roofs under tephra weight, and damaging agricultural crops and livestock. The eruption column reached the stratosphere, and satellite imagery tracked the ash plume as it extended thousands of kilometers across South America and over the Atlantic Ocean.

The eruption ejected an estimated 0.27 km³ of tephra (dense rock equivalent approximately 0.11 km³), classified as VEI 4 — the largest eruption in Chile since the 2011 Puyehue-Cordon Caulle event. Petrological analysis of the erupted material revealed a mixture of crystal-poor andesitic pumice and denser lithic fragments, with evidence that the eruption was triggered by the rapid injection of hotter basaltic magma into the shallow andesitic reservoir. The sudden onset became an internationally studied case in volcanic hazard assessment — the lack of clear precursory signals challenged existing monitoring paradigms and prompted discussion about the fundamental limits of eruption forecasting for open-vent andesitic volcanoes where deep-seated triggers can produce surface eruptions faster than conventional monitoring can respond. The photographs and videos of the eruption — particularly the lightning-laced mushroom cloud towering over the serene waters of Lake Llanquihue in the fading twilight — became some of the most widely shared volcanic images of the decade.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Since April 2015, Calbuco has returned to relative quiescence. SERNAGEOMIN maintains a monitoring network including seismometers, GPS, gas sensors, and webcams. Post-2015 analysis revealed that while subtle seismic and gas changes had occurred in the weeks prior, these were insufficient for confident advance warning. Research into the rapid magma-injection trigger has informed improvements in monitoring approaches including enhanced real-time seismic analysis and satellite-based InSAR deformation monitoring. Scientists emphasize Calbuco should be considered capable of future eruptions with similarly short warning times.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content:
The 2015 eruption vividly demonstrated Calbuco's hazard potential. Primary hazards include explosive eruption columns producing widespread tephra fall that can disrupt aviation, contaminate water, damage agriculture, and collapse roofs; pyroclastic flows descending the steep flanks at speeds potentially exceeding 100 km/h; lahars (volcanic mudflows) generated by rainfall mobilizing fresh ash deposits or by interaction of hot volcanic material with seasonal snow and ice on the upper slopes; and lava dome growth with associated dome-collapse pyroclastic flows, as occurred at the conclusion of the 1893-1894 eruption.

The proximity of significant populations amplifies the risk considerably. Puerto Montt, the capital of the Los Lagos Region with approximately 250,000 inhabitants, lies approximately 30 km to the south. Puerto Varas, a major tourist town with roughly 40,000 residents, sits 20 km to the north on the shore of Lake Llanquihue. The town of Ensenada, at the volcano's northwestern base, is even more directly exposed. The total population within 100 km of the summit exceeds 400,000. During the 2015 eruption, ashfall reached Puerto Montt and caused significant disruption to daily life and economic activity.

The particular challenge at Calbuco is the demonstrated potential for eruptions with minimal warning time. The 2015 event showed that the transition from apparent quiescence to full-scale VEI 4 eruption can occur in as little as three hours. For comparison, most well-monitored stratovolcanoes provide days to weeks of precursory seismicity and ground deformation before major eruptions. SERNAGEOMIN and Chilean civil defense authorities maintain updated evacuation plans for multiple eruption scenarios, and the 2015 experience — in which evacuations were executed rapidly and effectively despite the extremely short warning — demonstrated that Chile's volcanic emergency response capabilities are among the most developed in Latin America.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Calbuco is a broad, elongated stratovolcano with its summit ridge oriented SW-NE, standing prominently above the Chilean Lake District. The 400-500 m wide summit crater hosts a lava dome complex. Slopes grade from barren volcanic rock near the summit through valdivian temperate rainforest at lower elevations. Lake Llanquihue lies immediately northwest, and Osorno volcano (2,652 m) rises 30 km to the northeast. Together with the surrounding lakes, they form one of Chile's most celebrated landscape ensembles. The late Pleistocene debris avalanche deposit forms low hummocky terrain between the volcano and lake.

climate_and_global_impact.content: The 2015 eruption (VEI 4) injected SO₂ and ash into the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere but was insufficient for global climate effects. Regional impacts were significant: ashfall disrupted aviation in Chile and Argentina, contaminated water supplies, and damaged agriculture. The early Holocene VEI 5 eruptions would have had larger atmospheric signatures, potentially producing detectable regional cooling comparable to other large Holocene Andean eruptions.

cultural_significance.content: Calbuco occupies a prominent place in the cultural landscape of Chile's Los Lagos Region. The Mapuche indigenous people have a long relationship with the region's volcanoes. In modern Chilean culture, the 2015 eruption became a defining event — the dramatic photographs of the eruption column over Lake Llanquihue symbolized both the beauty and danger of living alongside active volcanoes. Calbuco's name likely derives from Mapudungun (Mapuche language), possibly from kallfuko meaning 'blue waters,' referencing nearby lakes.

visiting_and_tourism.content: The Chilean Lake District surrounding Calbuco is one of South America's premier tourist destinations. Puerto Varas offers panoramic views of Calbuco and Osorno reflected in Lake Llanquihue. While Calbuco itself lacks an established trekking route comparable to Villarrica, it adds dramatic backdrop to the region's scenery. Alerce Andino National Park on Calbuco's southern slopes preserves ancient alerce forest with hiking trails. The best time to visit is December through March (austral summer).

nearby_volcanoes.content: Calbuco's nearest volcanic neighbor is Osorno (2,652 m), approximately 30 km northeast, which last erupted in 1869. Further south, Chaiten stunned scientists in 2008 with a sudden eruption after 9,000 years of dormancy. The Puyehue-Cordon Caulle complex produced a major VEI 5 eruption in 2011. Villarrica, approximately 250 km north, is one of Chile's most active volcanoes. Llaima is another highly active Andean stratovolcano further north.

etymology.content: The name 'Calbuco' is believed to derive from Mapudungun, the language of the Mapuche people. The most cited etymology connects it to kallfuko, meaning 'blue waters,' referencing surrounding lakes and waterways. The nearby town of Calbuco, a historic fishing port, shares the name.

eruption_timeline.label: Largest historical eruption, concluded with dome emplacement
Sudden VEI 4 eruption with no warning — global media event

facts: Calbuco's April 2015 eruption occurred with virtually no precursory warning — only hours of mild seismicity preceded the violent VEI 4 event.
Photographs of the 2015 eruption cloud with volcanic lightning over Lake Llanquihue became some of the most widely shared volcanic images in history.
The eruption column from April 2015 reached approximately 15 km into the atmosphere.
Two eruptions in the early Holocene (~8460 and ~6760 BCE) reached VEI 5, an order of magnitude larger than 2015.
A late Pleistocene collapse produced a 3 km³ debris avalanche reaching Lake Llanquihue.
Approximately 4,000-6,500 people were evacuated within hours of the 2015 eruption.
The 1893-1894 eruption was one of the largest historical eruptions in southern Chile.
Puerto Montt (population ~250,000) lies just 30 km from the summit.
The 2015 eruption prompted international discussion about limits of eruption forecasting.
Magma mixing — injection of hot mafic magma into a cooler reservoir — is the suspected trigger for the 2015 event.
Calbuco and Osorno together form one of Chile's most iconic volcanic landscape pairs.
The name likely derives from Mapudungun kallfuko, meaning 'blue waters.'

faqs.question: When did Calbuco last erupt?
faqs.answer: Calbuco last erupted on April 22-30, 2015, in a sudden and violent VEI 4 event. Two major explosive pulses occurred on the evening of April 22 and early morning of April 23, producing eruption columns reaching approximately 15 km altitude, pyroclastic flows on multiple flanks, and heavy ashfall across the Chilean Lake District and into Argentina. The eruption occurred with virtually no precursory warning, making it one of the most surprising major eruptions in recent South American history. Prior to 2015, Calbuco's last eruption was a minor VEI 2 event in 1972.

faqs.question: Why did the 2015 Calbuco eruption happen without warning?
faqs.answer: The 2015 eruption occurred with minimal precursory signals because the trigger mechanism was rapid magma injection from depth rather than gradual pressurization of a shallow reservoir. Post-eruption research revealed evidence of magma mixing: hotter magma from deeper in the system was injected into a cooler shallow reservoir, causing rapid destabilization. This process happened too quickly for conventional monitoring to detect classic warning signs. The event highlighted the challenge of forecasting eruptions at andesitic volcanoes where deep triggers can bypass shallow warning systems.

faqs.question: Is Calbuco dangerous?
faqs.answer: Yes, Calbuco is considered one of Chile's most hazardous volcanoes. The 2015 eruption demonstrated its ability to produce violent VEI 4 eruptions with virtually no warning. The hazard profile includes explosive eruption columns, pyroclastic flows, lahars, and heavy ashfall. Approximately 400,000 people live within 100 km, including Puerto Montt (population ~250,000) just 30 km south. The geological record shows Calbuco has produced VEI 5 eruptions in the past, indicating potential for events larger than 2015. SERNAGEOMIN maintains continuous monitoring and evacuation plans.

faqs.question: How tall is Calbuco?
faqs.answer: Calbuco stands at 1,974 m (6,476 ft) above sea level. While modest compared to some Andean volcanoes, its summit rises prominently above the low-lying Chilean Lake District terrain, making it conspicuous from Puerto Montt, Puerto Varas, and Lake Llanquihue. The summit is capped by a 400-500 m wide crater hosting a lava dome complex enlarged by successive eruptions. Neighboring Osorno reaches 2,652 m and Villarrica stands at 2,847 m.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Calbuco?
faqs.answer: Calbuco is classified as a stratovolcano (composite volcano), built from alternating layers of andesitic lava flows and explosive tephra deposits. The dominant rock type is andesite to basaltic andesite, which produces eruptions ranging from moderate lava effusion to violent explosive events. The summit hosts a lava dome complex, indicating that some eruptions produce viscous magma that piles up at the vent. The volcano's elongated SW-NE profile reflects structural control by regional faults. A late Pleistocene edifice collapse and debris avalanche demonstrate the volcano's capacity for catastrophic sector failure.

faqs.question: Can you see Calbuco from Puerto Varas?
faqs.answer: Yes, Calbuco is clearly visible from Puerto Varas, a popular tourist town on the western shore of Lake Llanquihue, approximately 20 km from the volcano's summit. On clear days, Calbuco and neighboring Osorno volcano are both visible from the lakefront, creating one of Chile's most iconic volcanic landscape views. During the 2015 eruption, residents of Puerto Varas had a dramatic front-row view of the eruption column and volcanic lightning. The town received measurable ashfall during the eruption.

faqs.question: How does Calbuco compare to the 2011 Cordon Caulle eruption?
faqs.answer: Calbuco's 2015 eruption (VEI 4) and the 2011 Puyehue-Cordon Caulle eruption (VEI 5) are the two largest volcanic events in Chile in the 21st century. The 2011 eruption was larger in scale, producing more voluminous ash deposits and disrupting international aviation for weeks, including flights across the Southern Hemisphere. However, Calbuco's eruption was more sudden, with virtually no precursory warning compared to the days of seismic unrest before Cordon Caulle. Both eruptions demonstrated the significant volcanic hazard across the southern Chilean Andes.

faqs.question: Will Calbuco erupt again?
faqs.answer: Calbuco is considered very likely to erupt again, though the timing cannot be predicted. The volcano has produced 36 recorded eruptions over approximately 10,000 years of Holocene history, with historical eruptions in 1893, 1906-1945 (multiple events), 1961, 1972, and 2015. The 2015 event demonstrated that Calbuco can transition from apparent quiescence to full-scale eruption in hours. SERNAGEOMIN maintains continuous monitoring, and evacuation plans are in place for surrounding communities. The geological record shows the volcano is capable of eruptions even larger than 2015.

schema_data.name: Calbuco
schema_data.description: An active 1,974 m stratovolcano in Chile's Lake District, famous for its sudden VEI 4 eruption in April 2015
